Hi I’m Niharika and welcome back to a new
lesson. Today we are gonna look at some idioms

related to human body. Now we’ve done a
lesson before on body noises and different

parts of body. But to be fluent, I thought
that idioms is a great idea. So here we have
some idioms for you and let’s get started.
The first one is, Beat ones head against the wall. Now what does that mean?

It means when you
are trying something really hard to achieve

something and you’re not successful. It
means that you’re wasting your time. You

are beating your head against the wall, so
it means that all your attempts are failing,

so all your attempts are failing to achieve
something and basically you’re wasting your

time. So for example, my cousin she’s just
bought a new dog, a little puppy, whose adorable.

But she’s been trying to potty train him
and it’s just taking forever. She’s just

wasting her time, because the dog is just
not learning. So it means she is beating her

head against the wall. She’s wasting her
time trying to potty train the dog. So that’s

how you can use this idiom. The next one that
I have for you is , Sight for sore eyes. Now

sight for sore eyes means something that you
find extremely pleasing. It’s like complete

treat for your eyes. You’re extremely glad,
you’re happy to see something or someone.

So you’re extremely happy to see someone
or something. So probably if you’re starving

and then someone presents a nice meal in front
of you. Oh yes that sure is a sight for sore

eyes, because you’re already starving, you’re
hungry and then you find some good food right

in front of your eye, so it is sight for sore
eyes. That’s how you can use this idiom.

The third idiom that I have for you is Pain
in the neck. There are so many people, who

end up using this idiom and trust me it’s
quite interesting. It means that you are bothered

or being annoyed by someone. I’m sure you
come across a lot of people, who love to annoy

you or bother you, so which means that they
are being pain in the neck. To be annoyed

by someone, so if you have a colleague , where
you’re working, you have a colleague, who

keeps bothering you, troubling you, when you
are trying to get your work done. It means

that he’s being a pain in the neck, so you
can use this idiom for such people, for such

annoying people. The forth one that I have
for you is, Wash your hands off. Now wash

your hands off a problem or a situation. It
means that you are just letting it go, you

don’t care anymore, you’re not bothered.
It’s none of your business, so which means

that you’re washing off your hands of a
problem or a situation. You don’t wanna

deal with it; you refuse to deal with it.
So you refuse to deal with the problem. Now

most of couples, I have observed that they
argue over something, so probably their son’s

behaviour, the mother is extremely upset and
she keeps telling her husband, that you know,

please don’t wash your hands off the situation.
He’s your son, so which means the husband

is least bothered. He like refuses to deal
with his son’s problems, so that’s how

you can use this idiom. And then the fifth
one is, Weak at the knees. When you go weak

at the knees. It means you are very nervous.
So you might have come across people, who

say that, I’m just going weak at my knees.
Which means they are extremely nervous? Probably

you see a very attractive man and if he comes
and talks to you, you get really nervous,

you get those butterflies in your stomach,
which means you are going weak at the knees.

Also if you have to do a presentation and
you have to present it in front of a big crowd

and you get very nervous. So yes that’s
when you can use this idiom. You can say,

Oh my god, this big crowd is making me go
weak at the knees. Which means that you are

extremely nervous? The next one is Cast iron
stomach. Well cast iron stomach means, you

have a very strong stomach. You can withstand
that food, something that is just so unpalatable

and your stomach can still stand it. It’s
just basically you never feel nauseated or

you never feel sick to your stomach, you just
have this cast iron stomach. A very strong

stomach. So if you end up eating a lot of
spicy food, hot peppers, jalapenos and still

you don’t feel sick. Which means you have
a cast iron stomach? And then the last idiom

that I have for you related to the body human
body is, Land on your feet. Now land on your

feet means that to recover quickly from a
very bad experience or a very bad situation,

probably you failed in a business, you went
into a big loss or probably you fell sick,

but you have recovered really fast. Which
means you have landed on your feet? So I have

this friend of mine, whose extremely lucky,
he always lands on his feet. The reason because

he works hard, it’s not that he gives up
easily even after a big downfall, he’ll

just recover quick. So which means he lands
on his feet, so that’s how you can use these

idioms, this would help you to speak fluently,
so go ahead please use

them  and I’ll be back with a new lesson soon.
Till then  you take care....
